intro: Lindernia intrepida, commonly known as the wild mint or redstem lindernia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Verbenaceae and is characterized by its slender, upright stems and clusters of small, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are often hairy and have a slightly minty aroma, which contributes to its common name. Lindernia intrepida is known for its adaptability to arid environments and is often found in dry, open habitats.
